title: Statistics
text: Statistics is about collecting, organizing, analyzing, and interpreting data. These skills help us make sense of information and make informed decisions.

title: Statistics
text: Statistics is about collecting, organizing, analyzing, and interpreting data. These skills help us make sense of information and make informed decisions.

title: Statistics
text:
Key Topics

Data Collection
Methods of gathering information:

Surveys and questionnaires
Observations
Experiments
Sampling methods
Primary vs. secondary data

Example: To find out students’ favorite sports, we could conduct a survey of the class.


Organizing Data
Ways to arrange and present data:

Frequency tables
Tally charts
Grouping data into intervals
Creating categories

Example: Tally chart of favorite colors in class


Displaying Data
Visual representations of data:

Bar graphs and column graphs
Line graphs
Pie charts
Pictographs
Dot plots
Stem-and-leaf plots

Example: A bar graph showing the number of students who prefer different subjects.


Measures of Central Tendency
Finding typical or middle values:

Mean: The average of all values

Formula: Sum of all values ÷ Number of values

Median: The middle value when data is ordered
Mode: The most frequent value

Example: Find the mean of: 4, 7, 5, 9, 5
Solution: Mean = (4 + 7 + 5 + 9 + 5) ÷ 5 = 30 ÷ 5 = 6


Range and Spread
Understanding how data varies:

Range: Maximum value - Minimum value
Quartiles and interquartile range
Outliers (unusual values)

Example: For the data set 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, the range is 11 - 3 = 8


Interpreting Data
Making sense of statistical information:

Reading and understanding graphs
Drawing conclusions from data
Identifying trends and patterns
Understanding bias and misleading graphs



Box-and-Whisker Plots
Visualizing the distribution of data:

Five-number summary (minimum, Q1, median, Q3, maximum)
Identifying the spread of data
Comparing data sets

Create a frequency table for the following ages: 13, 14, 13, 15, 14, 13, 14, 15, 13
Draw a bar graph showing: Apples-5, Oranges-8, Bananas-6, Grapes-3

title: Ratios and Proportions
text: Ratios and proportions describe relationships between quantities. They are fundamental to understanding scaling, comparison, and many real-world applications.

title: Ratios and Proportions
text: Ratios and proportions describe relationships between quantities. They are fundamental to understanding scaling, comparison, and many real-world applications.

title: Ratios and Proportions
text:
Key Topics

Understanding Ratios
Comparing quantities:

Ratios show the relationship between two or more quantities
Written as a:b or \(\frac{a}{b}\)
Simplifying ratios to simplest form
Part-to-part vs. part-to-whole ratios

Example: If there are 12 boys and 8 girls in a class, the ratio of boys to girls is 12:8 = 3:2


Equivalent Ratios
Finding equal ratios:

Multiplying or dividing both parts by the same number
Using ratio tables
Scaling up and down

Example: The ratio 4:6 is equivalent to 2:3 (dividing by 2) or 8:12 (multiplying by 2)


Proportions
When ratios are equal:

A proportion is an equation showing two ratios are equal
Cross multiplication to solve proportions
Direct proportion relationships

Example: Solve: \(\frac{3}{5} = \frac{x}{15}\)
Solution: \(5x = 3 \times 15\), so \(5x = 45\), therefore \(x = 9\)


Sharing in Ratios
Dividing quantities according to ratios:

Dividing amounts into given ratios
Finding total parts
Calculating each share

Example: Share $60 in the ratio 2:3
Solution: Total parts = 2 + 3 = 5
First share = $ = \(24\)
Second share = $ = \(36\)


Rates
Special ratios comparing different units:

Speed (distance per time)
Unit rates (per 1 unit)
Price per item
Comparing rates

Example: If you travel 180 km in 3 hours, your speed is:
\(\text{Speed} = \frac{180 \text{ km}}{3 \text{ hours}} = 60 \text{ km/h}\)


Scale Factors
Ratios in enlargement and reduction:

Scale drawings
Maps and models
Enlargement and reduction
Similar shapes

Example: A model car has a scale of 1:24. If the model is 15 cm long, what is the actual car length?
Solution: Actual length = 15 × 24 = 360 cm = 3.6 m


Direct Proportion
When quantities increase together:

If one doubles, the other doubles
Graphing direct proportion (straight line through origin)
Formula: \(y = kx\) where k is constant

Example: If 3 pens cost $6, how much do 7 pens cost?
Solution: Cost is proportional to number of pens
\(\frac{3}{6} = \frac{7}{x}\), so \(3x = 42\), therefore \(x = 14\) ($14)


Percentages as Ratios
Connecting percentages to ratios:

Percentages are ratios out of 100
Converting between percentages and ratios
Percentage increase and decrease

title: Ratios and Proportions
text:
Practice Problems

Simplify the ratio 24:36
If the ratio of cats to dogs is 5:3 and there are 15 cats, how many dogs are there?
Share $120 in the ratio 3:5
A car travels 250 km in 5 hours. What is its average speed?
On a map with scale 1:25000, two towns are 8 cm apart. What is the actual distance?

title: Ratios and Proportions
text:
Real-World Applications

Cooking and recipes
Currency exchange
Scale models and maps
Mixing paint or chemicals
Financial planning
Construction and design

title: Number and Operations
text:
Number and operations form the foundation of mathematics. In this unit, we’ll develop fluency with different types of numbers and operations.


The summary below draws on the Phase 4 Number table and the Year 9–10 teaching sequences in the resources folder: resources/NZC - Mathematics and Statistics Phase 4 (Years 9–10).htm, resources/-Mathematics-and-Statistics-Yr-9-Teaching-Sequence-.pdf, resources/-Mathematics-and-Statistics-Yr-10-Teaching-Sequence-.pdf.








Focus area
Year 9 emphasis
Year 10 emphasis




Number structures and operations
Scientific notation form; negative exponents; rational numbers between any two numbers; equivalent fractions; number line representations; convert and compare fractions/decimals/percentages; rounding and estimation for reasonableness; order of operations; reciprocals; integer and fraction/decimal operations; negative number equivalence.
Irrational numbers and special symbols; exponent rules; rules for roots and like roots; calculation with scientific notation; exact calculations with fractions, roots, and multiples of \(\pi\); significant figures; integer exponents with positive/negative numbers.


Rounding, estimation, and precision
Use rounding and estimation to predict results and check reasonableness; round to context.
Use rounding to specified significant figures; apply significant-figure rules in calculations and scientific notation.


Percentages, ratios, rates, and proportion
Percentages as fractions of 100; find parts/wholes from percentages; proportional increase/decrease; ratios (part–part, part–whole), rates, and scaling; divide quantities using ratios.
Percentage increase/decrease between two numbers; apply proportional change; compare and use ratios and rates (e.g. speed).


Financial mathematics
Apply mark-ups, discounts, simple interest, and GST in context.
Convert currencies; unit-cost/proportion problems; compound interest via repeated simple-interest calculations over short periods.



Key vocabulary focus (Phase 4): GST, index, irrational number, like roots, original amount, precision, rate, reciprocal, recurring, scientific notation, simple interest, compound interest, principal square root, significant figures (see resources/NZC - Mathematics and Statistics Phase 4 (Years 9–10).htm and the Year 9–10 teaching sequences).

title: Number and Operations
text:
Key Topics

Integers
Working with positive and negative numbers:

Understanding the number line
Adding and subtracting integers
Multiplying and dividing integers
Real-world applications of negative numbers

Example: If the temperature is -3°C and it rises by 7°C, what is the new temperature?
Solution: -3 + 7 = 4°C


Fractions
Operations with fractions:

Equivalent fractions
Adding and subtracting fractions
Multiplying and dividing fractions
Mixed numbers and improper fractions

Example: Calculate \(\frac{2}{3} + \frac{1}{4}\)
Solution: \(\frac{8}{12} + \frac{3}{12} = \frac{11}{12}\)


Decimals
Understanding and using decimal numbers:

Place value
Adding and subtracting decimals
Multiplying and dividing decimals
Converting between fractions and decimals

Example: 3.5 × 0.4 = 1.4


Percentages
Working with percentages:

Understanding percentages as fractions of 100
Converting between percentages, decimals, and fractions
Finding percentages of amounts
Percentage increase and decrease

Example: What is 15% of 80?
Solution: 15% × 80 = 0.15 × 80 = 12

title: Number and Operations
text:
Practice Problems

Calculate: (-5) + 8 - (-3)
Simplify: \(\frac{3}{4} \times \frac{2}{5}\)
Find 25% of 160
Convert 0.625 to a fraction in simplest form

title: Welcome to Year 9 Mathematics
text:
This website contains resources, lessons, and materials for our Year 9 Mathematics class. The content is organized according to the New Zealand Mathematics Curriculum.


In Year 9, we’ll explore the following mathematical topics:

Number and Operations: Working with integers, fractions, decimals, and percentages
Algebra: Patterns, equations, and algebraic thinking
Geometry: Shapes, angles, and geometric properties
Measurement: Length, area, volume, and units
Statistics: Data collection, analysis, and interpretation
Probability: Chance, outcomes, and predictions
Ratios and Proportions: Relationships between quantities




By the end of Year 9, you will be able to:

Apply mathematical concepts to solve real-world problems
Use mathematical reasoning to justify your solutions
Communicate your mathematical thinking clearly
Work collaboratively on mathematical tasks
Develop confidence in your mathematical abilities




Click on any topic in the navigation menu to begin exploring the content. Each section includes:

Key concepts and definitions
Worked examples
Practice problems
Additional resources




Don’t hesitate to ask questions during class or reach out for extra support. Mathematics is a skill that develops with practice and perseverance!

title: Algebra
text: Algebra is the language of mathematics. It allows us to describe patterns, relationships, and solve problems using symbols and variables.

title: Algebra
text: Algebra is the language of mathematics. It allows us to describe patterns, relationships, and solve problems using symbols and variables.

title: Algebra
text:
Key Topics

Variables and Expressions
Understanding algebraic notation:

Variables represent unknown or changing values
Writing algebraic expressions
Evaluating expressions by substitution

Example: If \(x = 5\), evaluate \(3x + 7\)
Solution: \(3(5) + 7 = 15 + 7 = 22\)


Simplifying Expressions
Working with algebraic terms:

Collecting like terms
Expanding brackets
Factorizing simple expressions

Example: Simplify \(5x + 3 - 2x + 7\)
Solution: \(5x - 2x + 3 + 7 = 3x + 10\)


Solving Linear Equations
Finding unknown values:

One-step equations
Two-step equations
Equations with brackets
Equations with variables on both sides

Example: Solve \(2x + 5 = 13\)
Solution: \[\begin{align}
2x + 5 &= 13 \\
2x &= 8 \\
x &= 4
\end{align}\]


Patterns and Sequences
Recognizing and describing patterns:

Number patterns
Geometric patterns
Finding the nth term
Linear sequences

Example: Find the next term in the sequence: 3, 7, 11, 15, …
Solution: The pattern increases by 4 each time, so the next term is 19.


Graphing Linear Relationships
Visualizing equations:

Plotting points on a coordinate plane
Drawing straight line graphs
Understanding gradient (slope)
Finding the equation of a line

Example: Graph the equation \(y = 2x + 1\)

title: Algebra
text:
Practice Problems

Simplify: \(4a + 3b - 2a + 5b\)
Solve: \(3x - 7 = 14\)
Find the 10th term of the sequence: 2, 5, 8, 11, …
Expand: \(3(x + 4)\)

title: Geometry
text: Geometry is the study of shapes, sizes, and positions of objects. In Year 9, we’ll explore properties of 2D and 3D shapes, angles, and transformations.

title: Geometry
text: Geometry is the study of shapes, sizes, and positions of objects. In Year 9, we’ll explore properties of 2D and 3D shapes, angles, and transformations.

title: Geometry
text:
Key Topics

Angles
Understanding and measuring angles:

Types of angles (acute, right, obtuse, straight, reflex)
Angles on a straight line (sum to 180°)
Angles around a point (sum to 360°)
Vertically opposite angles
Corresponding, alternate, and co-interior angles

Example: If two angles on a straight line are \(x\) and \(2x\), find their values.
Solution: \(x + 2x = 180°\), so \(3x = 180°\), therefore \(x = 60°\)


Triangles
Properties of triangles:

Types of triangles (equilateral, isosceles, scalene)
Angle sum of a triangle (180°)
Exterior angles of triangles
Congruent triangles

Example: In a triangle, two angles are 65° and 45°. Find the third angle.
Solution: \(180° - 65° - 45° = 70°\)


Quadrilaterals
Properties of four-sided shapes:

Squares, rectangles, parallelograms
Rhombus, trapezium, kite
Angle properties
Symmetry properties



Circles
Understanding circles:

Parts of a circle (radius, diameter, chord, arc)
Circumference and area
Relationship between radius and diameter

Example: If a circle has a radius of 5 cm, find its diameter.
Solution: Diameter = 2 × radius = 2 × 5 = 10 cm


Transformations
Moving and changing shapes:

Translation (sliding)
Reflection (flipping)
Rotation (turning)
Enlargement (scaling)



3D Shapes
Exploring three-dimensional objects:

Prisms and pyramids
Faces, edges, and vertices
Nets of 3D shapes

title: Geometry
text:
Practice Problems

Find the missing angle in a triangle with angles 42° and 68°
Calculate the angles on a straight line if one angle is three times the other
Name the quadrilateral with all sides equal and all angles 90°
Find the circumference of a circle with radius 7 cm (use π ≈ 3.14)

title: Measurement
text: Measurement involves quantifying attributes of objects and events. We’ll learn about different units and how to measure length, area, volume, and other quantities.

title: Measurement
text: Measurement involves quantifying attributes of objects and events. We’ll learn about different units and how to measure length, area, volume, and other quantities.

title: Measurement
text:
Key Topics

Units of Measurement
Understanding metric units:

Length: millimetres (mm), centimetres (cm), metres (m), kilometres (km)
Mass: grams (g), kilograms (kg), tonnes (t)
Capacity: millilitres (mL), litres (L)
Time: seconds, minutes, hours, days

Example: Convert 2.5 km to metres.
Solution: 2.5 km = 2.5 × 1000 = 2500 m


Perimeter
Measuring the distance around shapes:

Perimeter of rectangles and squares
Perimeter of triangles and other polygons
Perimeter of composite shapes

Example: Find the perimeter of a rectangle with length 8 cm and width 5 cm.
Solution: Perimeter = 2(8 + 5) = 2(13) = 26 cm


Area
Measuring the space inside shapes:

Area of rectangles and squares: \(A = l \times w\)
Area of triangles: \(A = \frac{1}{2} \times b \times h\)
Area of circles: \(A = \pi r^2\)
Area of composite shapes

Example: Find the area of a triangle with base 10 cm and height 6 cm.
Solution: \(A = \frac{1}{2} \times 10 \times 6 = 30 \text{ cm}^2\)


Volume
Measuring the space inside 3D objects:

Volume of rectangular prisms: \(V = l \times w \times h\)
Volume of cubes: \(V = s^3\)
Volume of cylinders: \(V = \pi r^2 h\)
Capacity and volume relationship

Example: Find the volume of a cube with side length 4 cm.
Solution: \(V = 4^3 = 64 \text{ cm}^3\)


Surface Area
Measuring the total area of all faces:

Surface area of rectangular prisms
Surface area of cubes
Using nets to find surface area

Example: Find the surface area of a cube with side length 3 cm.
Solution: A cube has 6 faces, each with area \(3^2 = 9\) cm²
Total surface area = \(6 \times 9 = 54\) cm²


Scale and Maps
Working with scaled representations:

Understanding scale ratios
Using scales to find actual distances
Map reading

Example: On a map with scale 1:50000, a distance is 4 cm. What is the actual distance?
Solution: Actual distance = 4 × 50000 = 200000 cm = 2 km

title: Measurement
text:
Practice Problems

Convert 3500 mL to litres
Find the perimeter of a square with side length 7 cm
Calculate the area of a circle with radius 5 cm (use π ≈ 3.14)
Find the volume of a rectangular prism with dimensions 6 cm × 4 cm × 3 cm

title: Probability
text: Probability is the study of chance and likelihood. It helps us predict and understand uncertain events in mathematics and everyday life.

title: Probability
text: Probability is the study of chance and likelihood. It helps us predict and understand uncertain events in mathematics and everyday life.

title: Probability
text:
Key Topics

Basic Probability Concepts
Understanding chance:

Probability measures how likely an event is to occur
Probability scale: 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain)
Expressing probability as fractions, decimals, and percentages

Example: The probability of rolling a 3 on a standard die is \(\frac{1}{6}\)


Theoretical Probability
Calculating probability using logic:

Formula: \(P(\text{event}) = \frac{\text{number of favorable outcomes}}{\text{total number of possible outcomes}}\)
Sample space (all possible outcomes)
Equally likely outcomes

Example: What is the probability of drawing a heart from a standard deck of 52 cards?
Solution: \(P(\text{heart}) = \frac{13}{52} = \frac{1}{4} = 0.25 = 25\%\)


Experimental Probability
Probability based on trials and experiments:

Conducting experiments
Recording results
Calculating relative frequency
Comparing theoretical and experimental probability

Example: If you flip a coin 50 times and get 28 heads, the experimental probability is \(\frac{28}{50} = 0.56\)


Probability Language
Describing likelihood:

Impossible (probability = 0)
Unlikely (probability between 0 and 0.5)
Even chance (probability = 0.5)
Likely (probability between 0.5 and 1)
Certain (probability = 1)



Simple Events
Working with single outcomes:

Probability of simple events
Complementary events: \(P(\text{not A}) = 1 - P(\text{A})\)
Mutually exclusive events

Example: If the probability of rain is 0.3, what is the probability it won’t rain?
Solution: \(P(\text{no rain}) = 1 - 0.3 = 0.7\)


Tree Diagrams
Visualizing probability:

Representing outcomes systematically
Calculating probabilities of multiple events
Understanding combined events



Probability in Games
Understanding fairness and strategy:

Fair vs. unfair games
Expected outcomes
Making predictions

Example: In a game where you win if you roll a 5 or 6, the probability of winning is \(\frac{2}{6} = \frac{1}{3}\)

title: Probability
text:
Practice Problems

What is the probability of rolling an even number on a standard die?
A bag contains 5 red balls, 3 blue balls, and 2 green balls. What is the probability of drawing a blue ball?
If \(P(\text{event}) = 0.65\), find \(P(\text{not event})\)
You flip a coin twice. What is the probability of getting two heads?

title: Probability
text:
Real-World Applications

Weather forecasting
Sports predictions
Insurance calculations
Game design
Risk assessment

title: Mapping the School Farm
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text: Google My Maps is a free tool for creating a farm plan, measuring distances and areas, and recording work done on the property. This guide helps you map our school farm features and plan future work.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
1. Getting Started

Go to https://www.google.co.nz/mymaps and sign in to your Google account. If you do not have an account, create one.
Click “Create a new map”.
Click “Untitled map” to rename your map (for example, “Kaikorai Valley College School Farm”).

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
2. Setting Up Layers
Layers help organize your map. You can toggle them on and off to see different features.

Existing Features: Click “Untitled layer” and rename it to “Existing”. Use this for current paddocks, dams, and fences.
Proposed Work: Click “Add layer” to create a second layer named “Proposed” for future projects like new planting or fencing.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
3. Locating the Farm

Use the search bar to type in the school’s address or use the mouse scroll wheel to zoom into the property.
Recommended Style: Click the arrow next to “Base Map” and select Satellite. This provides a clear aerial view of the land.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
4. Drawing Farm Features

Adding Markers
Use markers for point-specific features like water tanks, sheds, or troughs.

Click the Marker icon below the search bar.
Click the exact spot on the map to place it.
Give the marker a title and click save.



Drawing Lines (Fences & Waterways)

Click the Line icon and select “Add line or shape”.
Click along the path of the fence or creek.
Press “Enter” to finish the line.



Mapping Paddocks (Areas)

Follow the same steps as drawing a line.
Instead of pressing Enter, click back on your starting point to “close” the loop and create a shape.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
5. Measuring Distances and Areas
The Measurement tool (Ruler icon) is helpful for planning.

Click a starting point and move the mouse to see distance.
If you measure a closed shape (like a paddock), it will show both the perimeter distance and the area in hectares.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
6. Exporting and Printing
To include your map in a report, you have two main options:

Google Print Tool: Click the three vertical dots next to the map name and select “Print map”. You can choose PDF or Image output.
Snipping Tool: Use your computer’s built-in screenshot tool (e.g., Shift + Command + 4 on Mac) to capture a specific area.


Source: Adapted from Beef + Lamb New Zealand User Guide #13.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
Learning Goals

Create a digital farm map using layers.
Add points, lines, and areas with clear labels.
Measure distances and paddock areas accurately.
Export or print a clean map for your workbook.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
2. Set Up Layers
Layers let you separate existing features from proposed work. You can turn layers on or off using the checkbox next to each layer.

Rename the first layer to Existing. Use this for current paddocks, dams, fences, buildings, and water points.
Click “Add layer” and name it Proposed for future work such as new planting or fencing.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
3. Locate the Farm

Use the search bar to type in the school address, or zoom using the mouse wheel and the + / - buttons.
Click the arrow next to Base map and choose Satellite for a clear aerial view.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
4. Add Farm Features

A. Markers (Point Features)
Use markers for water tanks, sheds, gates, troughs, or trees.

Click the Marker icon under the search bar.
Click the exact spot on the map.
Give the marker a clear title, then save.




B. Lines (Fences, Tracks, Waterways)

Click the Line icon (right of the marker icon) and choose “Add line or shape”.
Click along the path of the fence or creek.
Press Enter to finish the line and add a title.




C. Areas (Paddocks, Orchards, Bush)

Start the same way as a line.
Click around the boundary and then click the starting point to close the shape.
Add a title and save.



D. Edit or Delete Features
After saving a feature, a popup lets you edit color, line width, transparency, and description. You can also attach a photo or delete the feature using the trash bin icon.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
5. Measure Distances and Areas
The Measurement tool (ruler icon) helps you check distances or paddock sizes.

Click the ruler icon on the far right of the toolbar.
Click a starting point, then add points to measure a path.
For a polygon, close the shape to see both perimeter and area (in hectares).
Press Enter to finish a straight line measurement.
To stop measuring, click the hand icon or click anywhere on the screen.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
6. Export or Print Your Map

Option A: Print Map (Recommended)

Click the three vertical dots next to your map name.
Choose “Print map”.
Pick paper size, orientation, and output type, then click Print.
A new PDF preview opens in your browser. Use the print icon to save as PDF or print.




Option B: Screenshot (Snipping Tool)
Windows

Open Snipping Tool from the Start menu search.
Click New, then drag to select the area.
Save the image and insert it into your workbook.

Mac

Press Shift + Command + 4.
Drag to select the area.
The screenshot saves to the desktop for inserting into your workbook.

title: Mapping the School Farm
text:
Map Checklist

Your map has a clear title.
Layers include Existing and Proposed.
Features are labeled with correct names.
At least one line and one area are mapped.
Measurements are used to check a distance or area.
Export is clean and readable.
